abstracts.cdata!:
The study shows that employment,
            legalization of small-scale mining, enhancement of
            small-scale activities, and increase of official earnings
            enshrined in the project objectives have been effectively
            achieved.  However, two of the objectives, namely: improving
            mining skills, and access to equipment and capital, have not
            been effectively addressed.  Marketing of the precious
            minerals by small-scale mining leaves much to be desired.
            The study recommends the following: 1) more mineral lands of
            the large scale mining concerns be released to small-scale
            miners; 2) the project should form small groupings or
            cooperatives of small-scale miners to enable them to benefit
            from credit, tools and equipment lease or high-purchase; 3)
            the government should amend the small scale gold mining law
            to include limited prospecting and "blasting", and
            the inclusion of other precious metals; 4) marketing; 5)
            relationship between the project and the Precious Minerals
            Marketing Corporation (PMMC) should be streamlined to
            encourage transparency; 6) relationship between Mines
            Department and District Administration should be streamlined
            to ensure success of the second phase of the project; and 7)
            there should be proper needs assessment of the project
            officers to enable the project to develop a training programme.
